abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Rural Development (Mahakli
            Hills) Project in Nepal was achieved. The confidence of the
            Bank in the ability of line agencies to recruit and post the
            required number of staff appears to have been excessive. The
            Bank fielded a total of twelve supervised)on missions over
            the eight-year period of implementation, which was somewhat
            below requirements, particularly when considering that nine
            of them were one-man missions. More emphasis should have
            been placed on engineering and agronomic inputs into
            missions. The project achieved its objectives in
            establishing infrastructure and institutional bases for
            sustaining project activities. Building maintenance however
            remains a problem, especially in service centers outside
            district headquarters. The following are the main lessons
            that could be drawn from the experience of this project : As
            demonstrated during the last project extension, it is
            possible to achieve substantial targets in infrastructure
            development in remote areas, once communication links are
            functioning. the flow of funds is secured, a reasonable
            staff strength is maintained without excessive turnover and
            if a strong leadership is exercised from the PC's
            office. Overall, the project achieved the main objective of
            increasing production as well as improving the welfare,
            social and environmental conditions of rural hill people.
